intro: Loasa papaverifolia, commonly known as the Mexican poppy, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its showy, cup-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink and orange. It has palmate leaves with five to seven lobes, and its stems are often hairy. Loasa papaverifolia is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is adapted to grow in well-drained soils in full sun.
